resource.chars:
[paragraph]XII. <u>Results found by a second Observer<\u> qv.<u>as operator<\u>?. 
We may now consider the results of three series of 
observations made <u>by myself, in order to determine the 
relation of one observer to another in the perception of colour. 
The standard colours are connected by the following equation, 
as determined by six observations - 
18.1(24)+27.5(44)+37(68)=W*(17) 
The average errors in these observations were 
Table VIII 
R .28 G+B .83 G-B .83 
G .83 B+R .42 B-R .28 R+G+B .95 
B .16 R+G .95 R-G .72 
showing that in this case, also, the power of distinguishing 
<u>colour<\u> is more to be depended on than that of distinguishing 
degrees of <u>illumination<\u>. 

The average error in the other observations from the means 
was .64 for red, .76 for green, and 1.02 for blue 

Table IX 
Observations by J.C.M., Oct 1859
